title: Which presidential candidate will win Michigan?
preds: Well, I didn't see this one coming, even if Michael Moore did.
*This is definitely cheating - would work only in case GJO makes a mistake to include today in the scores (as indicated by resolution date)*
Polls still indicate a Clinton win.

Hillary has been up in every poll in Michigan, and these odds are similar to those Nate Silver is giving.  I think Hillary has an even higher chance of winning, but given that polling in Michigan was way off for Bernie Sanders v. Clinton (which Sanders won), I am hesitant to rely completely on the polls here.
Based on polling data and historical data, I show Clinton with between 53% and 68% odds of winning the votes that will matter. Best guess for her is 55%

Average of 5 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 6
CLINTON 48%
TRUMP 42%
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

This is a swing state, which has been solidly Democrat since the 1990s, though having voted Republican many times before that. Baseline is 65% Clinton. All the polls suggest a Clinton win, though the demographics are more favourable for Trump than many other states.
Decreased Hillary's odds in Michigan based on Bill Clinton needing to visit today (48 hours before he election).  Figured he wouldn't do so unless internal polls showed it was close.
Major polls + analysis stabilizing, Clinton should have this one in the bag.
Trump's penetration of white male working class vote offset by women's vote-and clinton's strength among highly educated whites in suburbs.

Average of 5 Polls
Last Poll: Nov. 4
CLINTON 47%
Trump 41%
Raised Hillary's odds based on recent polls in Michigan.
HC has been comfortably ahead, even now sporting a safe lead in the polling averages.

538 giving Clinton 76.4% prob of winning Michigan: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/ RCP polling average giving Clinton the lead, 46.3%, Trump	41.7%:
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/mi/michigan_trump_vs_clinton_vs_johnson_vs_stein-6008.html
DJT appeals to the unemployed workforce in this state.
While Trump is making new efforts in Michigan, Clinton's lead does not appear to be surmountable in the last few days before the election.

Trump has been gaining in the polls and is on a pretty good streak of not drawing negative attention to himself, while meanwhile Clinton continues to face new negative news including the whole FBI email thing.

Hillary Clinton has been winning in all recent polls and neither is spending much time there.  I heard Obama's campaign manager say that he was down in Michigan by as much as Trump is before eventually winning it though.   I put Hillary's chances a little bit above Nate Silver's.
Lowering very slightly due to minor poll declines by Hillary
Expect more tightening through end of week (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/#plus).

http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-yes-donald-trump-has-a-path-to-victory/, says if he gets national lead its on.  WaPo says he has one https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2016/11/01/post-abc-tracking-poll-clinton-falls-behind-trump-in-enthusiasm-but-has-edge-in-early-voting/?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_tracking-poll-740a%3Ahomepage%2Fstory.   This R leaning poll supports... http://dailycaller.com/2016/11/02/new-poll-clinton-45-trump-44-in-michigan/.    He is focussing here so his Social Media gurus mus think its real: http://news.sky.com/story/trump-takes-aim-at-clinton-leaning-states-michigan-and-wisconsin-10641582.  Not convinced but adjustment down against hrc.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Latest polls:
10/21/2016 MRG: CLINTON 46%, Trump 38%
10/24/2016 Mitchell research: CLINTON 49%, Trump 41%
10/26/2016 Mitchell research: CLINTON 50%, Trump 44%
10/27/2016 EPIC-MRA: CLINTON 41%, Trump 34%
10/28/2016 Emerson college: CLINTON 50%, Trump 43%
Adjusting for FBI investigation.  Still very likely, but much less certain than yesterday.
Adjusting for FBI investigation.  Still very likely, but much less certain than yesterday.
No poll forecast predicted that Michigan is in play. Trump is not even going there.
24 polls; probability of leading averaged. However, more recent polls show a much higher percentage than I'm estimating.
Although Michigan is a blue state, a recent drive through the state revealed that in many areas, the Trump signs far outnumber the Clinton signs.
Giving Trump a Rust Belt edge.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
I live in Michigan; I see no evidence of a shift toward Trump. I do think Trump will carry rural and blue collar areas, but will massively lose in the cities and educated suburbs
HRC's polling numbers have moved solidly into the low double digits and time is simply running out for DT, so I'm upping my numbers for HRC marginally.
Updating forecast.   Most recent polls: http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/mi/michigan_trump_vs_clinton-5533.html  Some give Hillary as much as a 10 point lead.
HRC Ground Game is superior....and normal midwestern people are f____ing fed-up with the non-sensical and narcissistic DT display.
If Utah is truly in play with 27 days to go, there's no point in being too cute or precise: Michigan is 100%. I will say 99% in deference to the Black Swan.
Methinks we have seen peak Trump.
upping Clinton, in line with wider trends

Polls are back up to around where they were before I went down to 83% for Clinton. Adjusting a little further up, since time is running out and for Trumps diminishing party support following the events of this past weekend.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Has been solid throughout the election cycle. Nothing to suggest a change.

Hillary Clinton is enjoying a groundswell of support in Michigan, with a poll released Thursday showing her previously narrow lead over Donald Trump has grown to 11 points in the last three weeks. (CNN)
It is no a Democratic primary anymore...
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

9/28/2016 Mitchell research
Clinton 49%
Trump 44% 9/30/2016 Glengariff group
Clinton 46%
Trump 39%

Trump is in trouble in this state. All sources agree on Hillary with a clear lead. http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/
https://www.predictit.org/Market/2132/Which-party-will-win-Michigan-in-the-2016-presidential-election
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner

Even with Trump's support among low-to-middle-income white voters, Michigan will probably continue its trend, since 1992, of support Democratic presidential candidates. Its still-strong union presence blunts Trump's white working class appeal. Combine that with a significant Arab-American and Muslim presence in the Detroit area, and  traditional black support for Democrats, and Clinton has the edge.
Trump was dismal in the debated and local politics will reflect that in Michigan.
Her lead holds well and is likely to increase after the first debate.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Re-evaluating on projection of 538 trend from mid-August. A toss up, unless US markets perform exceptionally over next ~month.
Same again, GD is showing only fake news from WP :D
Dropping HRC from 89 on 12 August, following http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/
Great line (paraphrased):  "It used to be they made the cars in Michigan and you couldn't drink the water in Mexico.  Now they make the cars in Mexico and you can't drink the water in Flint."

I don't believe Michigan will be a state that will go for Trump. It won't be close in the city, in the suburbs though it will no doubt go for Trump. I have cousins in Michigan - two own construction businesses and both are on that Trump train. They truly believe the system needs to be shaken up. I've adjusted my forecast. There are too many undecideds and I think hidden votes. Keeping a close eye on this.
Close one there. Lots of urban population will roll towards HRC, but lots of blue collars will go for Trump.
I'm adjusting to move closer to Trump advantage.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

EPIC-MRA 9/15/2016
Clinton 42%
Trump 38% Mitchell research
Clinton 47%
Trump 42%
gonna row back a bit on this one; Trump polling strongly on Ohio, Michigan hasn't seen much high-quality polling at all....plus it was the site of the biggest polling error in the primaries.
Although I am far more optimistic about Trump's chances generally than the consensus here on GJO the polls have not trended in Michigan as I expected. Big jump up for Hillary.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Double digit poll leads are now down to 5 - 6 points.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
Based on Michigan's voting records, it is safe to say that Michigan is a primarily Democratic state, and will therefore vote Hillary Clinton for the presidency.

Despite the August tightening in most polling, Clinton still enjoys a ~6 pt lead in Michigan—ranking 4th of 14 swing states—per fivethirtyeight: http://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-as-the-race-tightens-dont-assume-the-electoral-college-will-save-clinton/?ex_cid=538twitter
Looks like Clinton's lead is pretty persuasive as of now.
Last 2 polls have HRC up by 7 and 5 points, down from earlier double digit leads.

Newest polls I've seen show the race tightening a bit in Michigan. Meanwhile Trump has strung together a few weeks without any major negative headlines, while Clinton is facing further email and foundation questions.

All the usual sources suggest a big Hillary advantage: http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/#plus

A long time ago there was a dandy movie called "Fear Strikes Out."  It was about a member of the Boston Red Sox and not the Detroit Tigers, but fear strikes out again this year in Michigan.  It is almost heartwarming.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

Poll by Suffolk university 8/25/2016:
Clinton 44%
Trump 37%

updated, multi-model averaging from NYT Upshot
http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/upshot/presidential-polls-forecast.html?_r=0

Hillary Clinton leading polls by ample margin 
http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/mi/michigan_trump_vs_clinton-5533.html
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
I'm just amused that in the pie chart Donald Trump support is orange.
Even a modest turnout by Muslims and African-Americans will ensure this.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.

I think enough time has passed since the democratic convention, that I can put a little faith that Clinton's increasing poll numbers are not just post convention bounce. Also, overall all I'm feeling more like Clinton will win, so some of my reasoning for that naturally filters down to the state contests.
Trump needs to win " so good" to win Michigan. he is to controversial for this.

In Michigan, Democratic party won last six presidential elections.
Main polls show great lead for Mrs. Clinton. 
As for Mr. Trump, his national poll numbers continue to plunge...
Trump is digging holes deeper than he may be able to get out.
According to the general news, 538.com, PredictIt.com, and GJP consensus.
I'm using 538's polls-plus number for my initial priors in the state races: http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/#plus
Bearish on Trump due to his recent dip in the polls.
Polling is moving against Trump slightly more than it should. Somewhat lower expectations that the blue collar vote will make the difference.
Fine tuning to 538 and Upshot.  Rounding high, since I don't think Trump is going to get any better as pressure increases.
Trump's view of industrial America is well aligned with Michigan voters.
OK, we are now post conventions.  Trump has been trump, pulls have changed.  They should settle in a few weeks, but for now, leaving alone.  538 is around 83%, Upshot is 80%.  Waiting for more data.

Predictwise says 92%.  538 says 79%. Predictit gives 80%. Consensus estimate is 84%. Good Judgement gives 78%. http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2016-election-forecast/michigan/
https://www.predictit.org/Market/2132/Which-party-will-win-Michigan-in-the-2016-presidential-election
http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner No republicans in Michigan?

Per US Census: ~80% whites, 74% non-college educated plays right into Trump's base. The notable graying trend in Michigan's population (growing over-65 share, shrinking under-18 share) swings even more in favor of a conservative/Republican..

As of 8-1-16, Trump is toast.  By criticizing the mother of a soldier who sacrificed his own life to save his troops, Trump has lost the vote of every man and woman who ever wore a uniform, and their brothers and sisters and mothers and fathers and uncles and aunts and second cousins twice removed.  He can't raise any money and he can't control his narcissism.  He's burnt meat.
According to general news, gjp. and 538.com.
Flint water crisis is putting republicans on defensive

This one is going to be close Hillary should carry Detroit ,Ann arbor and Lansing and Flint. But will it be enough to win with the rest of state up in the air. The UAW doesn't have the cohesion as a voting block it had in the past. Sometimes it seems this state is in resentment of Detroit and all the tax dollars it gets.

Bernie Sanders won the Democratic primary in Michigan with 49.8% (595,222), Hillary Clinton received 48.3%
(576,795) Trump won the Republican primary by a large margin, in comparison, 36.5% (483,751) vs. Ted Cruz 24.9%
(330,015), Kasich 24.3% (321,655).   Most recent polls put Hillary in the lead by as much as 3-6 points.  But we shouldn't forget this is the state where Hillary had a supposed lead of 10 pts over Bernie Sanders and ended up losing.  So, I'd be cautious in relying too much on polling in the state.   http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/mi/michigan_trump_vs_clinton-5533.html Here's Michigan's presidential election voting history:  http://www.270towin.com/states/Michigan
The state has voted Democrat in the last 5 elections but for 2016, it's being considered as a swing state.

Most things will depend on the level of non college educated white voter registration and inclination to vote. The dynamic is different and although not carried by the Republican Party since 88 there is potential, at this point, that this might be a volatile state.
Democrat victories in last 3 presidential elections. Strong urban core.

Lead in Flint has poisoned  all state voters against the GOP governor it hurts Trump being in the same party as that guy. Detroit has a ton of Muslims and Muslim Churches are now doing voter registration drives.
The large numbers of minority voters in Michigan will be the difference, balancing out the votes from white blue collar voters giving Hillery an advantage.
Trump seems to be gaining in popularity lately in the Rust Belt, esp. after his VP pick from Indiana.
Michigan has a solid history of voting for the democratic party in Presidential elections. Detroit would heavily be in favor of Clinton.
Based on 2008 and 2012 voting record of Michigan for Democrats.

Majority of Michigan voters are in cities.  Historically, Detroit's black voters have voted Democrat.  The same is true for the black voters of other Michigan metropolitan areas.  Black voters recognize the historic and crucial need to vote in this election.  They will GOTV.
All polls lean toward Clinton, although they are all fairly tight.  If they were to vote today, I'd expect Clinton to win this state.
Previous history since 1988. All the polls put her in front. Kristy tried to palm off Pence to Michigan (little effect)

Okay... So Michigan is indeed a swing state that has voted Democrats in the past 5 elections. It has voted for Bernie over HIllary. According to most polls mentioned in an article I read (http://www.270towin.com/states/Michigan), Hillary is ahead. However, is this also logical? Although Bernie did endorse Hillary, some of his supporters (although not too many) will either go towards Trump or towards independents or will simply not vote. Again, these WILL (probably) BE FEW. The majority of Bernie's voters, I believe, will end up voting for Hillary. In raw votes, Hillary already secured more votes than Trump (again, roughly 100k more), but the total of voters for the Republicans were over 100k more (https://ballotpedia.org/Presidential_election_in_Michigan,_2016). The same patterns for Bernie's voters, I think, do not apply to anti-Trump republicans, and that is because neither Bernie nor Hillary have received as much negative attention as Trump, which will also pile up.  What I want to say is that, in a sense, for a Berniee to vote for Trump he would have to move far more to the right than a Republican voter would have to move to the left for Hillary.
90 % chance by PredictWise. Odd it is so high. http://predictwise.com/politics/2016-president-winner
Democrat strength on labor unions (somewhat tempered by Trump anti-trade stance), sizable minority population votes, disaffection for trump
It will be very interesting to see what attempts Trump is going to take to win over the established democratic union toe to the the republican side. Will we see a 40% swing? Hope so.

Trump is telling auto workers he will force companies to return American Jobs to the US.  Since Michigan's economy is dependent on auto industry and workers, they are going to be in favor of Donald Trump.

Michigan has been consistently a Democratic state in presidential elections recently.  Clinton's lead in polling is somewhat closer than expected given Obama's margins in 2008 and 2012, but she still has a decent lead.
Trump is very strong in Michigan.
Labor unions will get behind Hillary, so it won't even be close.
Given the prior voting history for the state (last 6 elections MI has voted democrat), I think it is highly likely that they continue to vote democrat.

Michigan is more Dem-leaning than OH or PA, so if the Wolverine state turns out to be remotely close, it'd be bad news for Hillary. Barring a major national shift, I think this is safely in the Dems' column.

Polling results have been aligning from March. Both candidates had not strong position in primary ballots
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_presidential_election_in_Michigan,_2016

The Republican Party currently holds a majority in both the House and Senate of the Michigan Legislature. Michigan supported the election of Republican Presidents Ronald Reagan and George H. W. Bush. The current Governor Rick Snyder (2011–present) is a Republican. Good for republicans.
 Michigan led the nation in job creation improvement in 2010. (During democrats rulling). It is good job statistic now in Michigan (not bad for republicans and democrats). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_unemployment_rate
Thought it over more after seeing how big of a win it was for Obama in 2012 (around 10%), I have a hard time seeing Clinton losing that much ground in this election against Trump.
Has voted Democrat in every election since 1992. Clinton has at least a 3%-7% lead in the polls I've seen.
Detroit will overwhelmingly vote against Trump.
According to general news, gjp. and 538.com.
For now, I'm going with the 538 polls-only forecast (which is more conservative than their polls-plus).

Factors counting for Dem victory: - Michigan has been Dem since 1992.
- Trump's cultural nativism doesn't have as much appeal in the midwest as on the east coast and south Factors for Repub victory: - Sanders won Dem primary (just), so not much Hilary enthusiasm, especially among white voters. Some 'berniebros' may go Trump.
- Trump's economic protectionism could be appealing
- Few Hispanic voters Conclusion: - Predict Dem victory as in previous decades, as I don't believe Trump's nativism and protectionism will win over more voters here than it loses.

Unions will have trouble getting a united front against Trump.  Reagan dems are Trump voters.
If Wayne county has a large turn out it will be close but outside Detroit area Clinton will lose to Trump.
Clinton will likely win the election. However, Michigan will be closer than expected due to strong Trump demographics.
Michigan has gone Democratic in every presidential election since 1992. Additionally, it has a sizeable African-American population (about 15%) for a Northern state, which will help Clinton.
Lots of blue collar white males will vote.
Repub turnout will be lower than expected
Anti-free trade sentiment and Clinton's lackluster performance in the democratic primacy, support for NAFTA,CAFTA and TPP will play in Donald Trump's favor.
Michigan voters will choose Mickey Mouse over Hillary.

Michigan history favors democrats. Obama won Michigan by 9+%. Start with 75% Hillary is leading by 7+%.  Small decrease in Obama lead; Change odds to 70%  Unless there is a sea of change, it seems Michigan is safe for Hillary.

Slight edge to Clinton based on the national polls.  Using the state polls, it may be better to evaluate changes in forecasts, due to differences in polling methodologies. Battle of the polls.  Trump looks better in Quinnipiac polls.  Clinton better in others.
Some media reports criticize Quinn's breakout of voter group percentages to under represent minorities.
Michigan is more consistently blue than most battleground states, and Clinton's reversal on the TPP might help her in these Rust belt states.
